SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<headline>
Here Is What Appears to Be Dylann Roof's Racist Manifesto
</headline>
<post id="p1" author="ThePlayDrive" datetime="2015-06-20T15:00:00">

Apparently two people found a website owned by the Charleston shooter by looking up his name in a WHOIS directly. (For those who don't know, WHOIS is system that allows you to look up domain names and their owners.) That website contained a manifesto which is ultimately just an uneducated, hateful rant about black people.

He talks about how "blacks are the real racists", how he thinks the media ignores "black-on-white" crime, how black people are violent, how black people are obsessed with race, how black people are easily offended and how the Trayvon Martin case was blown out of proportion. In other words, he makes pretty much every argument that conservatives make about black people and race, in general.
The following is the excerpt in which he describes his motive:

I have no choice. I am not in the position to, alone, go into the ghetto and fight. I chose Charleston because it is most historic city in my state, and at one time had the highest ratio of blacks to Whites in the country. We have no skinheads, no real KKK, no one doing anything but talking on the internet. Well someone has to have the bravery to take it to the real world, and I guess that has to be me.
Thoughts?
Source: Here Is What Appears to Be Dylann Roof's Racist Manifesto (http://gawker.com/here-is-what-appears-to-be-dylann-roofs-racist-manifest-1712767241)
</post>
<post id="p2" author="Sherman123" datetime="2015-06-20T15:18:00">
<quote orig_author="ThePlayDrive">

Apparently two people found a website owned by the Charleston shooter by looking up his name in a WHOIS directly. (For those who don't know, WHOIS is system that allows you to look up domain names and their owners.) That website contained a manifesto which is ultimately just an uneducated, hateful rant about black people.

He talks about how "blacks are the real racists", how he thinks the media ignores "black-on-white" crime, how black people are violent, how black people are obsessed with race, how black people are easily offended and how the Trayvon Martin case was blown out of proportion. In other words, he makes pretty much every argument that conservatives make about black people and race, in general.
The following is the excerpt in which he describes his motive:

I have no choice. I am not in the position to, alone, go into the ghetto and fight. I chose Charleston because it is most historic city in my state, and at one time had the highest ratio of blacks to Whites in the country. We have no skinheads, no real KKK, no one doing anything but talking on the internet. Well someone has to have the bravery to take it to the real world, and I guess that has to be me.
Thoughts?
Source: Here Is What Appears to Be Dylann Roof's Racist Manifesto (http://gawker.com/here-is-what-appears-to-be-dylann-roofs-racist-manifest-1712767241)
</quote>

I think it is important that we not give in to the usual clarion call to label him "mentally ill". This negation of belief, the rejection that someone like Dylan Roof could really believe what he believes without some sort of flaw is harmful. Increasingly we have a propensity to mark our enemies as ill, deranged, or broken by their environments. We look to their mental state, their upbringing, their economic status, their society, anything to try and find a reason for why they don't 'fit' into our liberal democratic model.
This is ruinous.

What are my thoughts? My thoughts are that this is a carefully, if crudely, thought out manifesto on race and politics that this young man clearly believes. That this kind of hatred sprang from a clear belief that what he was doing was right and that he accepted the ideological underpinnings of his actions without reservation. That this isn't the product of a deranged lunatic. That this is the product of someone who believes what he believes and created a coherent internal logic as to why he did.

The sooner that we accept that our enemies believe their own ideology, that they aren't broken wayward souls looking for either mental health treatment or greater education, the sooner we will win. Whether that enemy is ISIS or Dylan Roof.
</post>

He was confused, stupid and dangerous?
Maybe parents should be resonsible for what their kids do.
</post>

<img src="http://www.debatepolitics.com/images/smilies/icon_rolleyes.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Rolling Eyes" class="inlineimg">

It has come to light that Dylann Roof was in the habit of regularly abusing powerful psychoactive drugs (http://www.wnd.com/2015/06/big-list-of-drug-induced-killers/). It seems exceedingly likely that they played a far larger role in his actions than any of his political beliefs.

For that matter, the idea that "blacks are raping all of our women," or that organizations like the Skinheads or the KKK are needed to curtail such alleged problems, are hardly now, nor have they ever been, "Conservative" ideological staples either. I have no idea where anyone gets off claiming such a thing as such.

At worst, Mr. Roof's views would seem to paint him as being a fringe radical loon, with some rather preposterous and counter-productive interpretations of certain facts regarding race. As I already pointed out, it's far more likely that he was simply whacked out of his mind.

Hell! Going by the logic outlined in the OP, Atheism, Environmentalism, the SPLC's "Hate Group" lists, and Homosexuality were all to blame for the actions of the Family Research Council shooter of 2013.
Is that really a road you all want to go down?
</post>
<post id="p5" author="Sherman123" datetime="2015-06-20T15:38:00">
<quote orig_author="Gathomas88">
<img src="http://www.debatepolitics.com/images/smilies/icon_rolleyes.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Rolling Eyes" class="inlineimg">

It has come to light that Dylann Roof was in the habit of regularly abusing powerful psychoactive drugs (http://www.wnd.com/2015/06/big-list-of-drug-induced-killers/). It seems exceedingly likely that they played a far larger role in his actions than any of his political beliefs.

For that matter, the idea that "blacks are raping all of our women," or that organizations like the Skinheads or the KKK are needed to curtail such alleged problems, are hardly now, nor have they ever been, "Conservative" ideological staples either. I have no idea where anyone gets off claiming such a thing as such.

At worst, Mr. Roof's views would seem to paint him as being a fringe radical loon, with some rather preposterous and counter-productive interpretations of certain facts regarding race. As I already pointed out, it's far more likely that he was simply whacked out of his mind.

Hell! Going by the logic outlined in the OP, Atheism, Environmentalism, the SPLC's "Hate Group" lists, and Homosexuality were all to blame for the actions of the Family Research Council shooter of 2013.
Is that really a road you all want to go down?
</quote>

Why do you think that? You think because he popped suboxone that this drug played the decisive role on his decision to commit a massacre? As opposed to his stated beliefs, published manifesto, and years of racist attitudes and associations? It confounds me that we are never willing to take our enemies at their word. This is a problem I usually associate with liberals and it is concerning to see how easily it is bleeding into the conservative media cycle over this.
</post>
<post id="p6" author="ThePlayDrive" datetime="2015-06-20T15:39:00">
<quote orig_author="Sherman123">

I think it is important that we not give in to the usual clarion call to label him "mentally ill". This negation of belief, the rejection that someone like Dylan Roof could really believe what he believes without some sort of flaw is harmful. Increasingly we have a propensity to mark our enemies as ill, deranged, or broken by their environments. We look to their mental state, their upbringing, their economic status, their society, anything to try and find a reason for why they don't 'fit' into our liberal democratic model.
This is ruinous.

What are my thoughts? My thoughts are that this is a carefully, if crudely, thought out manifesto on race and politics that this young man clearly believes. That this kind of hatred sprang from a clear belief that what he was doing was right and that he accepted the ideological underpinnings of his actions without reservation. That this isn't the product of a deranged lunatic. That this is the product of someone who believes what he believes and created a coherent internal logic as to why he did.

The sooner that we accept that our enemies believe their own ideology, that they aren't broken wayward souls looking for either mental health treatment or greater education, the sooner we will win. Whether that enemy is ISIS or Dylan Roof.
</quote>

I agree with you when you say that this is manifesto created by someone who clearly believes what he writes. I also agree, based on what I know so far, that this is not a case of mental illness. I wouldn't disregard the effect that outside influences might have had on him (or other violent people) though. Even further, I do not believe that looking into the environment, circumstances and people that could influence someone to be so violent is not necessarily an attempt to "try and find a reason for why they don't 'fit' into our liberal democratic model". While some people certainly do that as a defense mechanism, others do it in an attempt to find the origins of a particular mindset.
</post>
<post id="p7" author="ThePlayDrive" datetime="2015-06-20T15:41:00">
<quote orig_author="JoG">
He was confused, stupid and dangerous?
Maybe parents should be resonsible for what their kids do.
</quote>
He doesn't seem confused. I don't know that he stupid either.
I don't think that holding parents responsible their adult son's actions is the right way to go, to say the least.
</post>
<post id="p8" author="JoG" datetime="2015-06-20T15:56:00">
<quote orig_author="ThePlayDrive">
He doesn't seem confused. I don't know that he stupid either.
I don't think that holding parents responsible their adult son's actions is the right way to go, to say the least.

It would make them pay more attention to their upbringing. And something must have gone terribly wrong there. And sure he is grown in a legal sense, but the warranty should go on for at least a decade.
</post>
<post id="p9" author="Gathomas88" datetime="2015-06-20T15:57:00">
<quote orig_author="Sherman123">

Why do you think that? You think because he popped suboxone that this drug played the decisive role on his decision to commit a massacre? As opposed to his stated beliefs, published manifesto, and years of racist attitudes and associations? It confounds me that we are never willing to take our enemies at their word. This is a problem I usually associate with liberals and it is concerning to see how easily it is bleeding into the conservative media cycle over this.
</quote>

Do I think flagrant abuse of substances known to trigger violence, delusion, and paranoia may have played a major role in the decision of a wild-eyed loner with a history of antisocial behavior to murder nine people in cold blood? Absolutely.
In no way, shape, or form was this a "rational," or even necessarily well thought out act. It wasn't a terrorist master stroke. Hell! There wasn't even a clear agenda behind it.
It was an act of psychotic impulse carried out by a clearly disturbed young man - nothing more and nothing less.
</post>
<post id="p10" author="a351" datetime="2015-06-20T16:08:00">
<quote orig_author="Gathomas88">

In no way, shape, or form was this a "rational," or even necessarily well thought out act. It wasn't a terrorist master stroke. Hell! <em>There wasn't even a clear agenda behind it.</em>
It was an act of psychotic impulse carried out by a clearly disturbed young man - nothing more and nothing less.
</quote>

That claim is not supported by the manifesto mentioned, the testimony of friends, or his statements directed towards the victims moments before the shooting. He literally spelled it out for us <img src="http://www.debatepolitics.com/images/smilies/New_Smilies/shrug.gif" border="0" alt="" title="Shrug" class="inlineimg">
</post>
